Rohingya - who, where, when, how?

Through the arrival of Arabs in the eighth century, Muslims settled in Arakan. The Muslim population living in this region later became known as Rohingya.

In the ninth or tenth century Arakan State was known as 'Rohan' or 'Rohhang', the origin of the word 'Rohingya' as a resident of that region. From when exactly this word is being used, its exact time is not known.

In the seventh century, survivors from a ship drowning in the Bay of Bengal say they have survived in the mercy of the Rohingyas. The word 'Rohingya' comes from this mercy.

But the Myanmar government does not recognize the existence of any word as 'Rohingya'. Rohingya Muslims in the western region of Burma, present day Burma, Muslim minority community About 20 lakh Rohingya in number, most of them

Not recognized as a citizen; In the near future, the Rohingya people live in different refugee camps in neighboring Bangladesh and Thailand, including the Rakhine state as a non-person.

Rohingya language

Rohingya language is the modern written language of the Rohingya community in Arakan State (Rakhine) of Myanmar. It belongs to the Indo-European language group, with which the regional languages ​​of Chittagong are similar. Rohingya researchers are from Arabic,

Using Hanifi, Urdu, Roman and Burmese scripts, have successfully been able to write Rohingya language. Hanifi is a neutral script which is made in Arabic and with four characters (Latin and Burmese).

Recently, a Latin script has been invented, which consists of 26 English letters and two additional Latin letters, for (for urgent R) and - (for nostrils).

In 1404, when the Pagan rulers of Burma captured Arakan, Arakan king Min-s-Moon (accordingly, King Narayikhala) escaped to the east and moved to Bengal. The Gaur Sultanate of Bengal was then under the Mughal empire of Delhi. After taking shelter with Min-Sa-Moon, he worked as a government servant under Gaur Sultan for a long time.

In 1429, Sultan Nadir Shah Khan-Min-Sa-Mun was encouraged to return his lost kingdom. With the help of Sultanate's arms and army, Min-Sa-moan succeeded in recovering his kingdom the following year. This resulted in the indirect rule of the Arakan king Gaur Sultanatan for 100 years from 1430 to 1531. At this time the Muslims grew in the region.

Although the Arakan kings of this period were Buddhists in religion, they used to hold the Muslim title of loyalty to the sultanate. Kalima and Persian script were introduced in the time of Arakanese coins. During this time, Ben-Su-Mun's brother Ali Khan and son-in-law, Kalima Shah, were named as Ba-So-Pru, respectively, to Ramu and some areas around Chittagong.

The state of Arakan expanded. During the reign of King Din-Bin, the 12th King Yuvaq Shah of this dynasty, got the final form of Arakan state prosperity from 1531 to 1553. He declared himself independent from the Sultanate of Bengal. King Min-bin recruits the Portuguese to build his army and Portuguese With the help of a strong naval force.
When the Bengal rulers declared independence against Mughal rule, Mughal Emperor Humayun attacked Bengal. In view of this unrest in Bengal, Arakan took over a large part of King Min-bin East Bengal.
